notes.title: Charge Properties
points: Electric charge is an intrinsic property of matter; types are positive and negative.
Quantization: Charge always exists in integral multiples of basic charge 'e' (1.6x10⁻¹⁹ C).
Coulomb's Law: Electrostatic force is proportional to charge product and inversely to square of distance.
Superposition Principle: Total force is the vector sum of individual electrostatic forces.

formulas.title: Coulomb's Law
formulas.explanation: Calculates the force between two stationary point charges.

formulas.title: Quantization
formulas.explanation: Calculation of total charge based on the number of surplus or deficit electrons.

realworld.title: Office Printing
realworld.description: Xerox machines use electrostatic charges to attract toner particles to the paper surface.

realworld.title: Atmospheric Events
realworld.description: Lightning is a massive discharge of static electricity between clouds or the ground.

topics.name: Electric Field and Electric Lines of Force

notes.title: Field Vectors
points: Electric Field (E) is the force experienced by a unit positive test charge.
Electric lines start from positive, end at negative, and never intersect.
Field lines are always normal to a conductor's surface.
Electric Dipole: Two equal and opposite charges separated by a small distance.

formulas.title: Field Strength
formulas.explanation: Defines electric field as force per unit charge.

formulas.title: Dipole Moment
formulas.explanation: Vector quantity representing the polarity and strength of a dipole.

realworld.title: Printing Technology
realworld.description: Inkjet printers use electric fields to deflect charged ink droplets for precise placement.

realworld.title: Cell Biology
realworld.description: Biological cell membranes maintain electric fields essential for nutrient and ion transport.

notes.title: Surface Flux
points: Electric Flux (Φ): Total number of electric lines passing through a given surface.
Gauss's Law: Total flux through a closed surface is 1/ε₀ times net enclosed charge.
Used to find E-field for infinite wires, plane sheets, and spherical shells.
Field inside a hollow charged conductor is always zero.

formulas.title: Gauss's Law
formulas.explanation: Relates the net flux through a closed surface to the internal charge.

formulas.title: Sheet Field
formulas.explanation: Electric field produced by an infinite non-conducting charged plane sheet.

realworld.title: Electronic Protection
realworld.description: A Faraday cage (like a car or plane body) protects the interior from external electric fields.

realworld.title: Data Transmission
realworld.description: Coaxial cables use Gauss's principle (shielding) to prevent external signal interference.

notes.title: Work and Energy
points: Electric Potential (V): Work done bringing unit positive charge from infinity to a point.
Equipotential Surfaces: Surfaces where potential is constant; E-field is always perpendicular.
Potential Gradient: Relationship between field strength and the change in potential.
System energy is stored as electrostatic potential energy.

formulas.title: Potential Definition
formulas.explanation: Relates electrical work done to the amount of charge moved.

formulas.title: Gradient Relation
formulas.explanation: Calculates field strength as the rate of potential change with distance.

realworld.title: Self Defense
realworld.description: Taser guns use high potential differences to deliver incapacitating electrical shocks.

realworld.title: Infrastructure
realworld.description: High voltage grids reduce energy loss over long distances by lowering current flow.

notes.title: Charge Storage
points: Capacitance (C): Ability of a conductor system to store electric charge.
Capacitor: Two conductors separated by an insulating dielectric layer.
Dielectrics increase capacitance by reducing the internal electric field.
Energy is stored in the electric field generated between the plates.

formulas.title: Capacitance Ratio
formulas.explanation: Defines capacitance as charge stored per unit potential difference.

formulas.title: Stored Energy
formulas.explanation: Calculates the total electrical potential energy held in the capacitor's field.

realworld.title: Photography
realworld.description: Camera flashes use capacitors to store charge and release it instantly for a burst of light.

realworld.title: Power Backup
realworld.description: UPS systems use large capacitors to provide bridge power during short transition spikes.

notes.title: Carrier Motion
points: Current (I): Flow of electrons through a conductor.
Drift Velocity (Vd): Average velocity of free electrons towards positive terminal.
Mobility (μ): Magnitude of drift velocity per unit electric field applied.
Relation: Current is directly proportional to the electron drift velocity.

formulas.title: Ohmic Relation
formulas.explanation: Calculates current based on potential and resistance.

formulas.title: Drift Equation
formulas.explanation: Relates bulk current to microscopic electron drift velocity.

realworld.title: Commuter Analogy
realworld.description: Analogous to road traffic, where vehicles move slowly despite the high density of cars.

realworld.title: Computing Hardware
realworld.description: High-performance computers focus on increasing electron mobility in semiconductor materials.

notes.title: Linear Conduction
points: Current through a conductor is proportional to voltage at constant temperature.
V-I graph is a straight line through the origin for ohmic conductors.
Ohmic (Metals) vs Non-ohmic (Semiconductors, Electrolytes) behavior.
Limitations: Fails at varying temperatures or in non-linear devices like diodes.

formulas.title: Voltage Balance
formulas.explanation: Fundamental law relating potential difference, current, and resistance.

realworld.title: Household Safety
realworld.description: Fuses and breakers are engineered using Ohm's law to prevent current overloads.

realworld.title: Consumer Electronics
realworld.description: Phone chargers convert high wall voltage to safe battery levels based on resistive logic.

notes.title: Opposition to Flow
points: Resistance (R) depends on length, area, material, and temperature.
Resistivity (ρ): Intrinsic property depending only on material and temperature.
Color Code: Standardized system for identifying resistor values accurately.
Internal Resistance (r): Opposition offered by the electrolyte inside a battery cell.

formulas.title: Resistivity Formula
formulas.explanation: Calculates resistance based on material properties and geometry.

formulas.title: Temp Dependency
formulas.explanation: Describes how resistance changes with variations in temperature.

realworld.title: Home Appliances
realworld.description: Nichrome wires use high resistivity to produce heat in toasters and electric heaters.

realworld.title: Medical Imaging
realworld.description: Zero-resistance materials cooled to low temps enable the powerful magnets in MRI machines.

notes.title: Work and Heat
points: Electrical Work: Energy required to maintain current in a steady circuit.
Joule's Heating: Thermal energy produced by current overcoming resistance.
Electric Power (P): Rate of electrical energy consumption in Watts.
Commercial Unit: kWh (Kilowatt-hour), equivalent to 3.6 million Joules.

formulas.title: Power Law
formulas.explanation: Calculates energy dissipation rate in an electrical component.

formulas.title: Thermal Energy
formulas.explanation: Calculates the total heat generated over time in a resistor.

realworld.title: Utility Billing
realworld.description: Smart meters track real-time energy usage in kWh for accurate residential billing.

realworld.title: Lighting Efficiency
realworld.description: Incandescent bulbs waste 95% of energy as heat, reflecting the heat side of Joule effects.

notes.title: Circuit Theorems
points: Junction Law (KCL): Sum of currents meeting at a node is zero (Charge conservation).
Loop Law (KVL): Sum of potential changes in a loop is zero (Energy conservation).
Wheatstone Bridge: Balanced four-resistor circuit used for precise resistance measurement.
Potentiometer: High-precision instrument for measuring EMF without drawing current.

formulas.title: Bridge Balance
formulas.explanation: Condition for zero current through the galvanometer in a Wheatstone bridge.

realworld.title: Engineering Design
realworld.description: Circuit designers use Kirchhoff's laws to calculate power distribution in smartphone boards.

realworld.title: Industrial Sensors
realworld.description: Strain gauges use Wheatstone bridge circuits to detect microscopic flexing in bridge supports.

Physics.chapterName: Magnetic Effects of Current and Magnetism
Physics.title: Magnetic Effects of Current and Magnetism

notes.title: Interaction Space
points: Space around a magnet or current where magnetic force is experienced.
Field lines: Closed loops from North to South (external) and South to North (internal).
Oersted's Experiment: Confirmed that moving charges produce magnetic fields.
Right-Hand Thumb Rule: Straightforward method to find B-field direction near wires.

formulas.title: Straight Wire Field
formulas.explanation: Calculates magnetic induction at distance r from an long straight wire.

realworld.title: Geography
realworld.description: Earth's magnetic field lines act as a guide for maritime and aviation compasses.

realworld.title: Transportation
realworld.description: Maglev trains use powerful repulsion fields to levitate and reach extreme speeds.

notes.title: Elemental Field
points: Gives flux density (dB) due to a microscopic current element (Idl).
Used to derive fields for circular loops and long conductores.
Field at a loop's center is inversely proportional to its radius.
B-field is always perpendicular to the displacement and current vectors.

formulas.title: Biot-Savart Law
formulas.explanation: Calculates the contribution of a small wire segment to the total magnetic field.

formulas.title: Circular Loop
formulas.explanation: Field strength at the exact geometric center of a current-carrying ring.

realworld.title: Clinical Diagnosis
realworld.description: MRI machines use massive current loops to generate intense imaging fields.

realworld.title: Precision Control
realworld.description: Industrial solenoids use precisely calculated fields to open and close fluid valves.

notes.title: Loop Integral
points: The line integral of B-field around a closed path matches μ₀ times the net current.
Analogue to Gauss's law for calculating fields in symmetric setups.
Primarily used for finding flux inside solenoids and toroids.
Field inside a long solenoid depends solely on turn density and current.

formulas.title: Solenoid Flux
formulas.explanation: Calculates the uniform field contained within a long helical coil.

realworld.title: Home Gourmet
realworld.description: Induction cooktops use high-frequency magnetic fields to excite iron molecules in pans.

realworld.title: High-Energy Physics
realworld.description: Toroidal magnets in particle accelerators keep charged ions in stable circular paths.

notes.title: Lorentz Dynamics
points: Lorentz Force: Combined interaction of electric and magnetic fields on a charge.
Magnetic force is zero if the charge is static or moving parallel to the flux.
Cyclotron: Acceleration device that cycles charges in magnetic fields.
Magnetic Force on Wires: Basis for all electromechanical conversion.

formulas.title: Lorentz Force
formulas.explanation: Describes the deflecting force on a charge moving through a magnetic field.

formulas.title: Orbital Radius
formulas.explanation: Calculates the radius of the circular path taken by a charge in a uniform field.

realworld.title: Motive Power
realworld.description: Electric motors turn electrical power into rotation using force on current loops.

realworld.title: Chemical Analysis
realworld.description: Magnetic deflection separates ions by mass to determine the composition of samples.

notes.title: Geomagnetism
points: Earth behaves as a massive bar magnet with tilted geographical poles.
Parameters: Magnetic Declination, Angle of Dip, and Horizontal component.
Neutral Points: Locations where external and Earth fields perfectly cancel.
Material Types: Diamagnetic (weakly repelled), Paramagnetic, and Ferromagnetic.

formulas.title: Dip Relation
formulas.explanation: Relates the angle of dip to the vertical and horizontal Earth field components.

realworld.title: Data Storage
realworld.description: Hard drives use ferromagnetic layers to store bits as tiny magnetized regions.

realworld.title: Bio-Navigation
realworld.description: Migratory birds use the dip and declination of Earth's field to fly thousands of miles.

notes.title: Flux Dynamics
points: 1st Law: Changing magnetic flux through a coil induces an EMF.
2nd Law: Magnitude of induced EMF is proportional to the rate of change of flux.
Magnetic Flux (Φ): Product of magnetic field and area perpendicular to it.
Induced current only exists in closed circuits.

formulas.title: Faraday's Law
formulas.explanation: Calculates the instantaneous induced EMF based on flux change rate.

formulas.title: Magnetic Flux
formulas.explanation: Determines total magnetic field lines passing through a surface area A.

realworld.title: Energy Production
realworld.description: Electrical generators convert mechanical rotation into electricity via rotating coils.

realworld.title: Emergency Gear
realworld.description: Uses a moving magnet through a coil to power an LED without external batteries.

notes.title: Reaction Principle
points: Direction of induced current opposes the change in flux that caused it.
Consequence of the Law of Conservation of Energy.
Eddy Currents: Circulating currents induced in solid metal blocks in a changing magnetic field.
Eddy currents produce heat and can be used for 'Electromagnetic Braking'.

formulas.title: Polarity Rule
formulas.explanation: The negative sign in Faraday's law represents this opposition.

realworld.title: Safety Systems
realworld.description: Roller coasters use eddy currents for smooth, friction-free emergency stopping.

realworld.title: Vehicle Tech
realworld.description: Eddy currents in a rotating aluminum cup provide speed indications for the dashboard.

notes.title: Magnetic Inertia
points: Self-Induction: Induction of EMF in a coil due to its own changing current.
Mutual Induction: Induction of EMF in one coil due to changing current in a nearby coil.
Inductance: Property of a coil to oppose change in current (unit: Henry).
Energy stored in Inductor = ½LI².

formulas.title: Self Induction
formulas.explanation: EMF produced by the coil's own change in current flux.

formulas.title: Mutual Induction
formulas.explanation: EMF induced in a secondary coil by the primary circuit's current.

realworld.title: Automotive
realworld.description: Cars use induction to step up 12V battery power to 20,000V for spark plugs.

realworld.title: Mobile Tech
realworld.description: Smartphone chargers use mutual induction between primary (base) and secondary (phone) coils.

notes.title: Periodic Flow
points: Current that changes magnitude and direction periodically.
RMS Value (Ir): Effective value that produces same heating as a DC current.
Peak Value (I₀): Maximum amplitude of the AC cycle.
Reactance: Opposition offered by capacitors (Xc) or inductors (Xl) to AC flow.

formulas.title: RMS Current
formulas.explanation: The effective DC-equivalent value for thermal power calculations.

formulas.title: Reactance
formulas.explanation: Frequency-dependent resistance offered by L and C components.

realworld.title: Residential Grid
realworld.description: Household power is typically 220V AC at 50Hz, optimized for efficient distance transmission.

realworld.title: Audio Engineering
realworld.description: Speakers use inductors and capacitors to direct correct frequencies to woofers and tweeters.

notes.title: Complex Impedance
points: Impedance (Z): Total opposition in an LCR circuit.
Resonance: Occurs when Xl = Xc, resulting in minimum impedance and maximum current.
Quality Factor (Q): Measures the sharpness of resonance peaks.
Power Factor (cos φ): Ratio of true power to apparent power consumed.

formulas.title: Total Impedance
formulas.explanation: Vector sum of resistance and net reactance in a circuit.

formulas.title: Resonant Freq
formulas.explanation: Frequency at which the circuit's current is highest for a given voltage.

realworld.title: Communication
realworld.description: Adjusting a capacitor changes the resonant frequency to lock onto a specific station.

realworld.title: Power Management
realworld.description: Modern inverters use LCR filters to provide smooth, usable power from batteries.

notes.title: Wave Properties
points: Produced by accelerating electric charges or fluctuating magnetic fields.
Waves are transverse: E, B, and propagation direction are mutually perpendicular.
Do not require a medium for propagation (can travel through vacuum).
Travel at the speed of light (c) in vacuum.

formulas.title: Wave Velocity
formulas.explanation: Calculates the speed of light based on vacuum permittivity and permeability.

formulas.title: Field Ratio
formulas.explanation: Relates the amplitudes of the electric and magnetic field vectors.

realworld.title: Space Exploration
realworld.description: Studying EM waves from distant stars allows us to understand the history of the universe.

realworld.title: Geolocation
realworld.description: GPS satellites use EM wave timing to calculate precise locations on Earth's surface.

notes.title: Frequency Bands
points: Groups: Radio, Microwave, IR, Visible, UV, X-ray, Gamma.
Visible spectrum: VIBGYOR (approx 400nm to 750nm).
Radio waves have lowest frequency; Gamma rays have the highest energy.
Ozone layer protects Earth by absorbing harmful high-energy UV radiation.

formulas.title: Energy Order
formulas.explanation: Ranking of waves by increasing frequency and photon energy.

realworld.title: Culinary Appliances
realworld.description: Microwaves rotate water molecules in food to generate heat quickly.

realworld.title: Aviation Security
realworld.description: X-rays are used at airports to scan luggage for restricted items without opening them.

notes.title: Wavelength Apps
points: Radio/Micro: Broadcast communication (TV, phones) and radar.
Infrared: Night vision, remote controls, and physical therapy heat treatment.
Ultraviolet: Sterilization of medical tools and detecting forged documents.
Gamma Rays: Radiotherapy for cancer treatment and industrial structural inspection.

formulas.title: Photon Energy
formulas.explanation: Planck's relation defining the energy carried by a single photon.

realworld.title: Home Electronics
realworld.description: Remote controls use infrared LEDs to send pulse codes to televisions.

realworld.title: Skin Protection
realworld.description: Sunscreens block UV-A and UV-B to prevent cellular DNA damage in skin.

notes.title: Optical Bending
points: Reflection: Light rays bouncing back; obeys standard angle rules and mirror formula.
Refraction: Path change when passing between media of different refractive indices.
Refractive Index (n): Ratio of light speed in vacuum to speed in the medium.
Lateral Displacement: Shift experienced by rays passing through parallel slabs.

formulas.title: Mirror Mirror
formulas.explanation: Relates object/image distances to focal length of a mirror.

formulas.title: Snell's Law
formulas.explanation: Describes the relationship between angles of incidence and refraction.

realworld.title: Driving Vision
realworld.description: Rear-view mirrors use curved surfaces to provide a wider field of view.

realworld.title: Illusions
realworld.description: Swimming pools look shallower due to light bending at the water-air surface.

notes.title: Light Trapping
points: Occurs when light travels from denser to rarer medium above the critical angle.
Critical Angle (θc): The specific incidence angle where refraction is exactly 90°.
Enables effects like diamond sparkle, desert mirages, and fiber signal travel.
Requires a medium of lower refractive index on the outside for trapping.

formulas.title: Critical Angle
formulas.explanation: Calculates the angle for absolute reflection based on refractive index.

realworld.title: High-Speed Web
realworld.description: Fiber optic internet transmits data as trapped light pulses over vast distances.

realworld.title: Surgery
realworld.description: Doctors use light-guiding fiber bundles to visualize internal organs without surgery.

notes.title: Lens Mechanics
points: Lens Maker's Formula: Guides manufacturing based on radii and material index.
Thin Lens Formula: Functional relationship for object and image positioning.
Power (P): Measured in Dioptres; inversely proportional to focal length.
Magnification: Ratio showing how much larger/smaller the image is compared to object.

formulas.title: Power of Lens
formulas.explanation: Calculates the focusing strength of a lens in dioptres.

formulas.title: Lens Formula
formulas.explanation: Essential equation for calculating image position v in thin lenses.

realworld.title: Vision Correction
realworld.description: Spectacles use concave or convex lenses to correct myopia and hypermetropia.

realworld.title: Photography
realworld.description: Camera lenses move internal elements to change focal length and magnification.

notes.title: Magnification Tools
points: Simple Microscope: Basic convex lens used for reading or inspecting small parts.
Compound Microscope: Dual-lens system for ultra-high magnification of tiny cells.
Astronomical Telescope: Uses large objectives to capture light from galaxies.
Resolving Power: Specific ability to differentiate between two very close points.

formulas.title: Visual Magnification
formulas.explanation: Calculates simple magnification at the near point D (25cm).

formulas.title: Telescopic Power
formulas.explanation: Relates the focal lengths of objective and eyepiece for distance viewing.

realworld.title: Craftsmanship
realworld.description: Gemologists use simple microscopes to check the clarity and cuts of expensive stones.

realworld.title: Cosmology
realworld.description: The Hubble Space Telescope captures galaxies billions of light-years away via reflection.

notes.title: Wavefront Basics
points: Every point on a wavefront acts as a source of secondary wavelets.
The new wavefront is the forward envelope of these secondary wavelets.
Used to provide wave-based proofs for laws of reflection and refraction.
Explains diffraction: why light spreads when passing through tiny gaps.

formulas.title: Phase Continuity
formulas.explanation: Definition of a wavefront in Huygens' construction.

realworld.title: Architecture
realworld.description: Designers shape theater walls so sound waves (secondary wavelets) reach every seat.

realworld.title: Natural Safety
realworld.description: Modeling how massive sea waves propagate and curve around coastal features.

notes.title: Wave Interaction
points: Superposition of coherent waves creating regions of constructive/destructive intensity.
Young's Double Slit Experiment (YDSE) provided proof for light as a wave.
Constructive: Waves add up in phase to create bright bands (maxima).
Coherent Sources: Sources with same frequency and constant phase difference.

formulas.title: Fringe Spacing
formulas.explanation: Distance between two consecutive bright or dark interference bands.

formulas.title: Path Condition
formulas.explanation: Relationship for bright fringe formation in interference patterns.

realworld.title: Visualization
realworld.description: Laser interference patterns record and replay 3D images of complex objects.

realworld.title: Specialty Glass
realworld.description: Lenses use destructive interference to eliminate surface glare and improve clarity.

notes.title: Corner Bending
points: Light waves bending around sharp edges or squeezing through small openings.
Single Slit: Produces bright central mark with secondary patterns of lower intensity.
Smaller slit relative to wavelength increases the spread of the pattern.
Resolution Limit: Minimal distance needed to see two objects as separate.

formulas.title: Spread Width
formulas.explanation: Determines the width of the central bright maximum in single-slit diffraction.

realworld.title: Optics Storage
realworld.description: Tiny pits on a CD act as a diffraction grating, reflecting white light as a spectrum.

realworld.title: Advanced Imaging
realworld.description: Very small apertures can cause diffraction blur, limiting the sharpness of photos.

notes.title: Vibration Plane
points: Process of restricting wave vibrations to a single geometric plane.
Only transverse waves (like light) can be polarized; longitudinal waves cannot.
Malus's Law: Intensity varies as the square of the cosine of the angle θ.
Brewster's Law: Reflected light becomes fully polarized at a specific angle.

formulas.title: Brewster's Angle
formulas.explanation: Calculates the polarizing angle for a material based on its refractive index.

formulas.title: Malus's Law
formulas.explanation: Determines outcoming intensity from two polarizers at angle θ.

realworld.title: Driving Gear
realworld.description: Polarized sunglasses block horizontal glare reflected from wet roads or water.

realworld.title: Electronics
realworld.description: Screens use liquid crystals and polarizers to control pixel brightness.

Physics.title: Dual Nature of Radiation and Matter

notes.title: Electron Emission
points: Emission of electrons from metal surface when light of suitable frequency hits it.
Discovered by Hallwachs and Lenard; proved light has particle properties.
Threshold Frequency (ν₀): Minimum frequency for emission to occur.
Saturation Current is proportional to light intensity; Stopping Potential depends on frequency.

formulas.title: Photoelectric Power
formulas.explanation: Calculates max kinetic energy based on stopping potential V₀.

realworld.title: Renewable Energy
realworld.description: Solar panels use photoelectric principles to convert sunlight directly into clean electricity.

realworld.title: Automation
realworld.description: Automatic doors use light beams and sensors; blocking the beam triggers the motor.

notes.title: Photon Mechanics
points: Based on the concept of Quanta (Photons): E = hf.
Photon energy overcomes Work Function (W₀) and provides Kinetic Energy (K).
Discovery earned Einstein the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.
Work Function is unique to each metal (e.g., Caesium has low W₀).

formulas.title: Einstein's Balance
formulas.explanation: Energy conservation equation for photon-electron interaction.

formulas.title: Threshold Relation
formulas.explanation: Relates work function to threshold frequency and wavelength.

realworld.title: Optics Technology
realworld.description: Night vision goggles convert sparse photons into readable electronic signals.

realworld.title: Photography
realworld.description: Digital cameras use the photoelectric effect to convert light into pixel data.

notes.title: Radiation Nature
points: Radiation behaves as waves in propagation and as particles in interaction.
Matter also exhibits wave properties under specific conditions.
Davisson-Germer Experiment confirmed electron wave nature using crystals.
Photons have momentum despite having zero rest mass.

formulas.title: Photon Momentum
formulas.explanation: Relates a particle's momentum to its associated wavelength.

realworld.title: Microscopy
realworld.description: Electron microscopes use short electron waves to image atoms with 1000x light detail.

realworld.title: Modern Computing
realworld.description: Quantum computing relies on the dual and probabilistic nature of subatomic particles.

notes.title: Matter Waves
points: Every moving object has an associated wave called 'Matter Wave'.
Wavelength (λ) is inversely proportional to momentum (p).
Significant for subatomic particles; undetectable for macroscopic objects.
Matter waves are probability waves, not electromagnetic.

formulas.title: de Broglie λ
formulas.explanation: Calculates the wavelength associated with a particle's motion.

formulas.title: Electron λ
formulas.explanation: Wavelength for an electron accelerated through potential V.

realworld.title: Material Science
realworld.description: Neutron and electron diffraction studies help visualize crystal stress and defects.

realworld.title: Data Storage
realworld.description: SSDs work because electrons can 'wave' or tunnel through thin insulating barriers.

notes.title: Atomic Postulates
points: Electrons revolve in circular orbits with quantized angular momentum (L = n*h/2π).
Stationary Orbits: Energy is radiated only during jumps; orbits themselves are stable.
Energy difference ΔE = hf = E₂ - E₁.
Limited to hydrogen-like atoms; doesn't explain Zeeman effect splitting.

formulas.title: Orbit Quantization
formulas.explanation: Bohr's condition for allowed stable electron orbits.

formulas.title: Energy Levels
formulas.explanation: Total energy of electron in the n-th Bohr orbit.

realworld.title: Visible Light
realworld.description: Neon and Sodium lamps emit specific colors as electrons jump between fixed Bohr orbits.

realworld.title: Astronomy
realworld.description: Spectroscopy allows astronomers to determine the chemical makeup of distant stars.

notes.title: Spectral Groups
points: Lyman Series: Transitions to n=1 (Ultraviolet).
Balmer Series: Transitions to n=2 (Visible region).
Paschen, Brackett, Pfund: Transitions to n=3, 4, 5 (Infrared).
Rydberg Constant (R) is used to calculate emission frequencies.

formulas.title: Rydberg Equation
formulas.explanation: Relates wavelength of emitted light to energy level transitions.

realworld.description: Precise emission frequencies maintain exact time for GPS and cellular networks.

realworld.title: Celebrations
realworld.description: Strontium and Barium chemicals produce firework colors via their unique atomic spectra.

notes.title: The Nucleus
points: Contains Protons and Neutrons, collectively called Nucleons.
Isotopes: Same Z (atomic number), different A (mass number).
Binding Energy: Energy released during nucleus formation.
Stability is highest for nuclei with maximum binding energy per nucleon (Iron-56).

formulas.title: Nuclear Radius
formulas.explanation: Calculates the size of a nucleus based on its mass number A.

formulas.title: Mass Defect
formulas.explanation: The difference in mass that converts into binding energy.

realworld.description: I-131 and other isotopes are used in medical scans to locate tumors or thyroid issues.

realworld.title: Power Generation
realworld.description: Energy is harvested via fission (splitting) or fusion (joining) of atomic nuclei.

notes.title: Unstable Nuclei
points: Radioactivity: Spontaneous emission of α, β, or γ rays.
Decay Law: Decay rate is proportional to the number of active nuclei present.
Nuclear Fission: Heavy nucleus (U-235) splits; releases massive energy.
Nuclear Fusion: Light nuclei (H + H) join; source of solar energy.

formulas.title: Exponential Decay
formulas.explanation: Calculates remaining nuclei after time t based on decay constant λ.

formulas.title: Mass-Energy
formulas.explanation: Einstein's relation showing energy release from mass conversion.

realworld.title: Archaeology
realworld.description: Measuring C-14 decay determines the age of fossils and ancient wood artifacts.

realworld.title: Cancer Care
realworld.description: Alpha particles are used to destroy localized cancer cells with extreme precision.

notes.title: Charge Carriers
points: Materials with conductivity between conductors and insulators (Si, Ge).
Intrinsic: Pure; n_e = n_h. Extrinsic: Doped to increase conductivity.
n-type: Doped with pentavalent impurity (extra electron).
p-type: Doped with trivalent impurity (missing electron/hole).

formulas.title: Mass Action Law
formulas.explanation: Product of electron and hole concentrations is constant for a given material.

realworld.title: Computing
realworld.description: Modern CPU and GPU chips are made of trillions of tiny semiconductor switches.

realworld.title: Displays
realworld.description: Semiconductors emit light more efficiently than traditional vacuum tubes or filaments.

notes.title: Junction Physics
points: Formed by joining p and n materials; creates a Depletion Layer.
Forward Bias: Allows easy current flow (low resistance).
Reverse Bias: Blocks current flow; creates small leakage current.
Zener Diode: Works in reverse breakdown as a voltage stabilizer.

formulas.title: Barrier Voltage
formulas.explanation: Min voltage required to push carriers across the depletion layer.

realworld.title: Power Supplies

realworld.title: Energy Systems
realworld.description: Solar cells are large area photodiodes that convert light into measurable voltage.

notes.title: Three-Terminal Nodes
points: Elements: Emitter, Base, Collector. Configuration: NPN or PNP.
Functions as a binary switch or a signal amplifier.
Common Emitter (CE) is most widely used for amplification circuits.
